The greatness and respect of twenty million readers: why write a column for Lifehacker
05 Nov 2019, 15:30 by Polina Nakrainikova
And how to do it.
What is a column
Every day, Lifehacker publishes about 40 materials about how you need and do not need to live. Most of them are prepared by a permanent team of authors: we demand that all sources of information be checked, personally tested, and if this is not possible, reinforce the material with the expert‚Äôs opinion. In general, everything is tough, more details about our standards can be found in editorial policy.
But sometimes an expert can give more than just a comment - then we ask him to share his knowledge or experience in the author‚Äôs column. A column is always material from a guest author whose personality and experience give this material additional value. In all other respects, this is the same Lifehacker text - honest, backed by proofs, and most importantly - useful for the reader.

Why do experts write columns on life hacker



Because this is a cool way to reach a wide audience: our site is read by more than 20 million people every month. We provide an opportunity to speak on a wide range of topics: about health and sex, technology and business, work and leisure, cooking and travel, and in general about lifestyle.
Author's columns on a broad topic collect tens of thousands of views - more or less depending on the interest of readers in a particular topic. The editors give columnists the right to add a link to their project in the text and thus introduce our audience to it.
The Lifehacker column is an additional recognition of your expertise in a particular issue.
Who can write a column
The one whom the editorial board considers an excellent specialist in his field. It can be either a professional with a wide audience, or just a person with special experience.
We love science columns where scientists talk about important things in simple terms, like the philologist and researcher of Game of Thrones Maria Steinman or the anthropologist Stanislav Drobyshevsky. Or texts where professionals share their secrets, like the editor Lyuda Sarycheva or the co-founder of the Either / Either podcast studio Lika Kremer. Materials that broadcast a new look at current problems: the fiery column of the feminist Zalina Marshenkulova or a selection of things that you don‚Äôt have to do in bed, from the authors of the podcast ‚ÄúIs this sex?‚Äù.
And finally, columns from people with unique experiences, whether it‚Äôs the experience of opening a coffee shop or living with an anxiety disorder. If you have a story to tell, we will help convey your story to a wide audience.
Sometimes a representative of a company that is expert in a topic of interest to the editorial office acts as a columnist - but at the same time, the column does not have and cannot have an obsessive PR of the company, as well as its regular references. If you want to talk about your company, it will be much more effective to contact our commercial editorial office.
We are distrustful of the columns from astrologers, life coaches, representatives of alternative medicine, business trainers without practical experience, psychics and shamans. The threat of a gypsy curse will not force us to change our minds ‚Äî perhaps then you should just try another publication.
How to become a columnist



Most often, the editorial office itself comes up with a column suggestion, but if you have something to tell, write to us at ask@lifehacker.ru with the subject ‚ÄúColumn: name‚Äù. Briefly describe your experience and idea of the material or send the finished text. It is important that it is not published anywhere before.
We are interested in a wide range of topics: health, business, repair, productivity, economy, law, science, unique life stories - you can familiarize yourself with the rubricator in more detail here. In personal stories, we value honesty, and in the columns from professionals, expertise in the issue and willingness to confirm it.
If you did not find a heading that fits your column, in any case, tell us about your idea - perhaps the editor will help you find a suitable niche for it on the site. There is a possibility that such a niche may not be - in any case, we promise to give a quick answer.
After the expert and the editors agreed on the topic, joint work on the material begins. All articles on Lifehacker are written according to our editorial policy: from it you can learn how we structure and format texts, we approach the language of presentation and facts. The latter are especially important: we are attentive to everything related to quotes, statistics and numbers. Where accuracy is needed, the editors will ask for a link to a credible source.
The editor will surely read all the articles of the columnists - he will also help to build the structure of the text, formulate a cool headline and correct small errors, if any. After the text is ready, we select the best time for publication for it - and now you are the Lifehacker columnist.
Writing useful material and gaining the respect of 20 million readers is easier than it sounds.
